key_points: Twitter permanently banned President Donald Trump's personal account and removed a tweet from Ayatollah Ali Khamenei's English account, suspending new posts on it.
Both critics and supporters of Trump accused Twitter of having double standards in its treatment of the two leaders.
Khamenei's account has history of posting strong comments against Israel, prompting discussions on Twitter's enforcement of its violence incitement policy.
U.S. FCC Chairman, Ajit Pal, highlighted Khamenei's anti-Israel posts as a concern for potential glorification of violence.
Jason Brodsky, policy director of United Against Nuclear Iran, criticized Twitter for not applying its incitement of violence policy uniformly.
A Twitter spokesperson defended the platform's actions, stating they focused on the harm presented by Trump's account, noting prior enforcement against world leaders.
Twitter plans to expand its 'government account' labeling to officials of nations beyond the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council.
Khamenei's controversial tweet called COVID-19 vaccines from the U.S., Britain, and France 'untrustworthy,' alleging attempts to 'contaminate' other nations.
Iranian activists called for Khamenei's account suspension for spreading misinformation about vaccines; Twitter removed the tweet.
BBC correspondent Nafiseh Kohnavard noted the confusion among Iranians over Twitter's decision, given the platform is blocked in Iran.
spokespersons: Ajit Pal (Chairman, U.S. Federal Communications Commission)
Jason Brodsky (Policy Director, United Against Nuclear Iran)
